Preimages under the A-hat and Witten genera

Jul 25, 2019

In the previous post, we argued that the Witten genus is surjective on the image of , where the target is the ring of integral modular forms. (We actually argued that it’s -adically and rationally surjective on the image of for all primes , but that’s sufficient.) It is therefore natural to ask: what are examples of String manifolds which hit the generators of the image of in ?

Before answering this, let’s figure out the analogous question for the other orientations we know about. The mod Euler characteristic is a surjection: its value on a product of real projective spaces is . The signature is a surjection: its value on a product of complex projective spaces is . The Atiyah-Bott-Shapiro orientation goes . This, too, is a surjection (we’d also given our own proof of surjectivity here). Let’s try to construct explicit manifold representatives of the generators of ; since , we need to lift , (in degree ), and (in degree ). This stuff is classical, but we’ll spell it out anyway because it’s fun.

First, note that admits two inequivalent spin structures (corresponding to the fact that ; but -spheres for admit unique spin structures), called the bounding and non-bounding spin structures. (Note that from the obstruction-theoretic perspective, orientability is equivalent to the trivializability of the tangent bundle over a -skeleton, while admitting a spin structure is equivalent to the trivializability of the tangent bundle over a -skeleton.) Since the frame bundle for is just , we find that these inequivalent spin structures correspond to double covers, of which there are only two: the connected and the disconnected one. The “non-bounding spin structure” gives a lift of to .

Let’s now turn to lifting of and . Milnor, in “Spin structures on manifolds” (page 201), writes down (without proof) generators of and : the generator in dimension is a Kummer surface , and the generator in dimension lifting is an -manifold such that is cobordant to . The Kummer surface is the hypersurface .

As an aside, let’s see why has a spin structure, and why it lifts . Define as the non-singular hypersurface in of degree (so it’s the zero locus of a homogeneous polynomial of degree whose derivative is nonvanishing at a nontrivial zero of the polynomial). (Saying “the” non-singular hypersurface is a priori incorrect; one has to do work to prove that all such hypersurfaces with the same and are diffeomorphic.) Then , where is the generator pulled back to . Since a complex manifold is spin if and only if is zero mod (in general, a manifold is spin if and only if its second Steifel-Whitney class vanishes), we find that is spin if and only if is even. Since , we find that is spin.

Now, the A-hat genus of a closed oriented -manifold is , and so since is (we’d usually write it as , but if you think aobut what’s really happening, e.g., in the homotopy fixed point spectral sequence, you’d see why it’s a ), we find that to prove that the A-hat genus of is , we just need to show that . This is a classical calculation: recall that the Hirzebruch signature theorem tells us that , and is . We also know that , so we only need to calculate the Chern classes of . How do we do this? Well, , and we know that , where is the normal bundle. Since is a hypersurface of degree , we find that is a line bundle, and that it’s actually the pullback of over to . Therefore, the total Chern class is . Therefore, and . We conclude that . But , since is a hypersurface of degree , and so we find that . Finally, we get that , as desired.

Finally, we turn to this -manifold , which is supposed to be . The A-hat genus of is supposed to be (this property makes a “Bott manifold”). First, note that according to this table, we know that is generated by and (the latter of which I’ll henceforth be thinking of as ), so it suffices to construct a spin -manifold with A-hat genus ; since admits a metric of positive scalar curvature, its A-hat genus vanishes (by Lichnerowicz, although this argument is really nuking a fly; we could’ve alternatively proved this by just calculation!), and so since (by requirement), we find that is cobordant to for some integer . This is sufficient, since in .

Next, note that a -dimensional manifold being almost parallelizable implies that it is spin, since . It therefore suffices to find an almost parallelizable -manifold with A-hat genus . Next, note that since is almost parallelizable, we also have for . Therefore, , and so (by Hirzebruch and the characteristic power series for the A-hat genus) the signature and the A-hat genus of are and . In particular, . As such, we’d like an almost parallelizable such that . At this point, we turn to the classical work of Kervaire and Milnor, where it’s shown (see, e.g., the theorem on p. 91 of this book) that there are almost parallelizable (constructed by plumbing) such that

(If we’d like to be zero without changing its A-hat genus, we can just add to it copies of (since and ) without changing its A-hat genus; we won’t do this, although some people use this convention.)

It doesn’t really matter, but let’s just note the following. First, is generated by this and , and second, and (since ). Since and , we have , and therefore is .

OK, that was quite a lot. Let’s now turn to the Witten genus. First, note that under the map (coming from the -ring map arising via the cusp on the compactified moduli stack of elliptic curves; see here), the element in dimension goes to (or its negative; I’m bad with signs). One can check fairly easily (unless I messed up my calculation) that our manifold actually lives in , and so we have a string manifold lifting (see also the example on page 89 of this book, which says that the Witten genus of our manifold is its A-hat genus times ; we know that the A-hat genus of is indeed ). How about (note that is not in the image of )? As explained on page 90 of the book linked to above (and the vanishing of most of the Pontryagin numbers of almost parallelizable manifolds), it suffices to find an almost-parallelizable -dimensional manifold with , so that , and therefore its Witten genus is . The Kervaire-Milnor manifold again saves us: in this case, the numerator of is , and so (since ), as desired.

What about lifting (which is in the image of )? We know this lifts to , since both and lift - and -adically, respectively. Note that since the Witten genus of the generator (described above) of is , there is no string -manifold such that the Witten genus of is . I have no idea how to construct such a -manifold (whose Witten genus is or ), even though I know it exists!

Added later: I guess we have a positive answer to the prize question raised in page 86 of the book linked to above: since there is an with Witten genus , we find that the manifold answers Hirzebruch’s question. Mike Hopkins already knew this; he stated the existence of such an answer to Hirzebruch’s question in his ICM address, but I guess this actually constructs such a manifold (although, to be fair, I haven’t yet finished the task detailed in the last paragraph of this previous post; hopefully I’ll get to it soon).

As for constructing a -manifold with Witten genus , I figured that surgery theory might help. This paper of Browder’s provides a sufficient condition for a simply connected CW-complex to be homotopy equivalent to a smooth closed -manifold:

  • needs to be a -dimensional Poincare complex, i.e., there should exist a class such that capping with induces an isomorphism (where coefficients are in any abelian group).
  • There is an oriented vector bundle over such that there is a map to the Thom space of , such that induces an isomorphism on top-dimensional homology.
  • If are the Pontryagin classes of , then the signature of the cup-product induced bilinear form on is equal to .

Moreover, if is the smooth closed -manifold to which is homotopy equivalent, then the stable normal bundle of is pulled back from along this homotopy equivalence. In fact, we can avoid the use of any surgery theory if we just want a manifold with a map to whose stable normal bundle is the pullback — surgery comes in if we want to be a homotopy equivalence. To get an with this weaker property, we just use the same trick appearing in the Pontryagin-Thom construction: choose the map so that is transverse to the zero section ; then, is a smooth closed -manifold whose stable normal bundle is (under the induced map ), for which .

Let’s return to the question of lifting . According to the above discussion, we really only need to construct a suitable -dimensional Poincare complex. What properties should this Poincare complex satisfy? According to the example beginning on page 85 of this document, we find that if is a smooth closed oriented -dimensional manifold with and (i.e., is a string manifold), then the Witten genus of is , so we’d like and . But and are defined entirely in terms of the Pontryagin classes and the fundamental class of , so we can just reduce to find a -dimensional Poincare complex whose A-hat and twisted A-hat genus satisfy the same property. We’d like to be able to write down the A-hat and twisted A-hat genera in terms of the Pontryagin classes; see, e.g., here for an explanation of how one could do this in Mathematica. Note that since vanishes, we have (this is on page 3 of the linked document)

and similarly,

So we have some concrete conditions necessary on our -dimensional Poincare complex and the associated . How can we find such a pair ?
